Award.AwardTitle: Toeplitz approach to the Uncertainty Principle
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is in the area of complex and harmonic analysis. It is concerned with the set of problems in harmonic analysis that fall under the heading of the Uncertainty Principle, a relative of the principle of the same name that arises in quantum mechanics. Stemming from the work of Norbert Wiener in mathematics and Werner Heisenberg in physics, the area of the Uncertainty Principle still presents many mathematical challenges, and the field has numerous applications to adjacent fields. Several classical problems associated with the Uncertainty Principle, problems posed decades ago by such prominent mathematicians as Norman Levinson, Andrei Kolmogorov, and Norbert Wiener, remain open. Certain of those problems will be studied in this project. Modern methods of complex and harmonic analysis that appeared in the last thirty years suggest new approaches to the classical challenges of the Uncertainty Principle. Two such problems, the so-called gap and type problems, have recently been solved by the principal investigator. These problems have a number of important applications in approximation theory, prediction theory, spectral theory of differential operators, and mathematical physics.

A new approach in the area of the Uncertainty Principle was developed in recent papers of Nikolai Makarov and the principal investigator. One of the main ingredients of the new approach is the use of Toeplitz operators, which explains the title of the project. Indeed, the next stage of the application of the Toeplitz approach in harmonic analysis and spectral theory is the focal point of this project. It contains several classical open problems. Among the topics of research to be pursued are the following: general completeness problems, which will expand the results on the "type" problem mentioned earlier; spectral problems for Schroedinger and Dirac operators; and a Toeplitz operator version of the so-called Krein-de Branges theory, which was designed to connect complex and spectral analysis. Successful completion of this research will create a new and systematic view of the large variety of problems in the area of the Uncertainty Principle. A part of this project will be done in collaboration with the principal investigator's graduate students at Texas A&M University. Several mini-courses on the Toeplitz approach to the Uncertainty Principle were recently given by the principal investigator at U.S. and international research centers. All of the courses are oriented towards young researchers and graduate students. Together with Nikolai Makarov and Mikhail Sodin, the principal investigator is working on a book that will contain a modern account of the Krein-de Branges theory and other topics related to the Uncertainty Principle.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Since the formulation of the Uncertainty Principle (UP) in Quantum Mechanics by  Werner Heisenberg in 1927 it became one of the important components of modern science. Various mathematical aspects of UP are still being studied by mathematicians and theoretical physicists. One of such areas, pertaining to problems of Harmonic Analysis, was the main area for this project. 

The area of UP in Harmonic Analysis contains many classical problems posed by such famous mathematicians as Norbert Wiener, Andrei Kolmagorov, Mark Krein and others. Many of these problems remain open. A recent approach to such problems, based on the use of the so-called Toeplitz operators, was recently developed by the PI jointly with N. Makarov (Caltech). It allowed to solve some of the longstanding problems and find new directions for resarch. Further development of the Toeplitz approach and its appliications was the focal point of this project.

One of the main published products of the project is the book "Toeplitz Approach to Problems of the Uncertainty Principle" written by the PI, which appeared in CBMS series, publised by NSF jointly with the American Math Society, in 2015. It contains the first systematic overview of the Toeplitz Approach, its methods and applications. The main part of the text includes solutions to the Gap and Type problems, recently found by the PI, as well asapplications to problems in Fourier analysis and spectral theory, based on PI's joint work with N. Makarov and M. Mitkovski (Clemson).

Among other outcomes is a solution of a classical problem on oscillation of Fourier integrals found in PI's joint paper with M. Mitkovski. A joint paper with N. Makarov  contained a new 'uncertainty' version of a classical result by Borg on the inverse spectral problem for Schroedinger operators. 

PI's graduate student, Ms. Rishika Rupam, who was partially supported by the project, has defended her PhD in May 2015. She has started a postdoctoral position  in the fall of 2015. PI's current students, M. Withanachchi and B. Hatinoglu, also supported by the project, continue their work on connections between spectral theory, complex analysis and analytic numbertheory.


In the fall of 2015 PI held a position of Distinguished Visiting Professor at Brown Univerisy. During his stay at Brown PI collaborated with S. Treil and gave a special topics course on the Toeplitz Approach to Uncertainty Principle directly related to the project. The course included several recent results obtained since the start of the project, along with classical theory and applications. It was attended by graduate students and faculty members.


During the report period the PI co-organized two conferences whose scientific scope lies within the general area of the project. The first conference took place in Saas-Fee, Switzerland, in 4/2016 and the second at Mittag-Leffler institute, Sweden, in 7/2016. 


Based on recent research partially supported by the NSF the PI was invited as a speaker to the International Congress of Mathematicians, Rio de Janeiro, 8/2018.
